Penn’s Grove eighth grader Emilee Jumper and her mom Angela have been busy since the COVID-19 quarantine began. Emilee wanted to do something special for the residents at Twin Pines Nursing Home in Chatham, PA, since her great-grandmother was a resident there for two months before she passed away.

So Emilee called Twin Pines and asked how many residents they had, which is 104. Mother and daughter decided to color 104 coloring pages and make 104 note cards.

On April 28 the Jumpers delivered one note card and one coloring page to each of the Twin Pines residents. They also have colored 40 additional pages which will be donated to the Eli Seth Matthews Leukemia Foundation to be sent to children with cancer.

If you and your family have taken on a project to help others during this crisis, send info and/or photos to asalatto@oxfordasd.org so your efforts can be highlighted on OASD social media.

On April 28 the Jumpers delivered one note card and one coloring page to each of the Twin Pines residents. They also have colored 40 additional pages which will be donated to the Eli Seth Matthews Leukemia Foundation to be sent to children with cancer.

If you and your family have taken on a project to help others during this crisis, send info and/or photos to asalatto@oxfordasd.org so your efforts can be highlighted on OASD social media.

Congratulations to Herr's, recipients of the Employer Governor’s Achievement Award at the recent PA Workforce Development Association annual conference! Herr’s was recognized for their partnership with our Norristown and York offices and Oxford Area School District to help students who happen to have #disabilities access real-life, work-based learning experiences. Now in its third year, this collaboration has expanded to include additional employment opportunities for students in warehousing, shipping and landscaping positions.

Thank you Herr’s for your partnership and for believing in the potential of students with #disabilities! #EmpoweringSuccess

Oxford Area High School students in Craig Carlough’s AP environmental science class, members of the Envirothon team, Diane Miller’s plant and soil and agricultural science classes, and the high school chapter of Future Farmers of America spent all day on April 25 planting approximately 450 trees on the school campus near Little Elk Creek. The project, in partnership with the Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay and the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, creates a natural barrier to keep pollutants from the creek and ultimately the Chesapeake Bay, one of America’s most vital and threatened habitats.

On April 5, OAHS senior Cameron Baughman, a member of E-Squad, champion of the eighth annual Dodgeball Tournament to benefit the Eli Seth Matthews Leukemia Foundation held on March 14, presented Foundation director Paul Matthews with a photo montage of all the teams that participated in the event, with the center image of E-Squad signed by all team members. Local photographer Mark Freisleben designed the montage and Cameron framed it with help from his mom, Wendy.

The Dodgeball Tournament is sponsored annually by the OAHS chapter of Future Business Leaders of America and celebrates the life and legacy of Mr. Matthews' son Eli, who worked tirelessly to raise money in the fight against leukemia before dying of the disease in 2011 at age nine. Mr. Freisleben wanted to do something special for this year's event, as Eli would have been graduating from OAHS in June.

Pictured with Cameron and Mr. Matthews is FBLA advisor Kim Webber, who organized the first Pennies for Patients fundraiser for Eli's Foundation in 2008 and each of the eight dodgeball tournaments.
